abstract: Among Web 2.0 startups, few are more closely watched than Facebook, a social-networking Web site that was originally restricted to college students but has since opened the gates to many others as well. Much of the fascination comes from the decision by Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s young founder, not to accept offers to acquire Facebook, including a bid from Yahoo that The New York Times said was worth $900 million. (Others have rounded it up to an even $1 billion.) In a long profile of the oft-profiled Mr. Zuckerberg, Fast Company’s Ellen McGirt spends some time pondering how Facebook’s founders and its investors — who include PayPal founder Peter Thiel — might eventually cash out their stakes.
